title: Polish commissioner candidate under investigation by EU anti-fraud agency
text:
Janusz Wojciechowski at the European Parliament in 2012 | Julien Warnand/EPA Polish commissioner candidate under investigation by EU anti-fraud agency German media says EU’s anti-fraud office is investigating Janusz Wojciechowski.

Poland's candidate for the next European Commission is under investigation by the EU's anti-fraud agency, OLAF, for alleged irregularities in the reimbursement of travel expenses, an OLAF spokesperson told Germany's Der Spiegel.

The allegations date back to Janusz Wojciechowski's time as an MEP between 2004 and 2014. The Polish commissioner candidate told Spiegel that he had paid back €11,250 for "insufficiently documented" travel expenses for the period 2009 to 2011 "on his own initiative."

According to the media report, however, the OLAF investigation relates to additional transactions and information from the European Parliament suggests the sums involved are "in the five-digit range."

Wojciechowski, a member of the European Court of Auditors and former deputy chair of the European Parliament’s agriculture committee, is believed to be in line to get the agriculture portfolio under Commission President-elect Ursula von der Leyen. Krzysztof Szczerski, who was originally appointed as Poland’s candidate, withdrew himself from consideration after von der Leyen proposed that the country get the agriculture portfolio.

She will officially present her team on Tuesday.

The Commission and von der Leyen's transition team didn't comment on the ongoing investigation, Spiegel reported.

Wojciechowski met von der Leyen last week, and told journalists on Thursday he was “very happy” with the conversation they had.
description: German media says EU’s anti-fraud office is investigating Janusz Wojciechowski.
